awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Collaborative robotics using discrete variable stiffness actuators
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of collaborative robot manipulators to allow full use of human intelligence and robotic precision and strength to improve industrial performance and safety. The proposed technology seeks to support manufacturing industries in automating their manufacturing processes by using collaborative robotic manipulators to complement their workforce. The proposed technology may speed up the adoption of co-robots in manufacturing industries to supplement the lack of skilled workers and release workers from repetitive and dangerous tasks to increase manufacturing efficiency with fewer accidents. In addition to manufacturing applications, this next generation of compliant co-robots also may be applied to logistics, military service, medical care, home companions, education, and other applications.
  
This I-Corps project is based on the development of collaborative robot manipulators using discrete variable stiffness actuators that provide both human safety and robotic performance.  Currently, existing variable stiffness actuators rely on continuous stiffness change mechanisms.  The proposed technology brings a discrete design methodology for fast stiffness level selection, low power consumption, zero back driving force in stiffness change, and compact design.  In addition, the proposed actuators provide a unique solution for the development of next generation of compliant robotic manipulators that may balance human safety (low stiffness) and robotic performance (high stiffness) using fast switching of representative stiffness levels. The proposed compliant actuators may be applied to sectors of the robotics industry that require adaptable compliant dynamics enabled by variable stiffness such as walking robots, exoskeletons, medical and educational robotics with human-robot physical interactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this project, a dedicated I-Corps team hailing from Purdue University at West Lafayette delved deep into the market demands surrounding collaborative robotic arms (cobots) and explored the potential commercialization avenues for a new cobot concept employing our patented discrete variable stiffness actuators. This novel technology not only ensures inherent safety through low mechanical compliance during human interactions but also boasts exceptional performance due to its high stiffness level adjustability.

The team embarked on a rigorous 7-week I-Corps training course, conducting extensive research that included over 100 in-depth interviews with key stakeholders such as engineers, sales managers, technicians, CTOs, and distributors from existing cobot and manufacturing companies. With site visits to more than 30 companies and active participation in major industrial automation exhibitions nationwide, coupled with numerous online discussions, the team diligently explored the landscape.

The team's comprehensive research shed light on the prevalent cobot solutions, primarily focused on material loading, assembly, and welding. These solutions, although slow-paced, are widely accepted in the industrial sphere. Surprisingly, the team discovered that physical human interactions, a realm they initially believed to be a prime market, were not as extensively integrated as expected. Rather than efficiency, the pain point within the industry resided in the seamless integration and automation setup within manufacturing plants and production lines.

Armed with these insights, the team pivoted their focus towards detailed physical human-robot interaction scenarios, particularly in fields like medical rehabilitation and massaging applications. These domains demanded close physical interactions but were more forgiving in terms of precision and payload requirements. Preliminary explorations indicated that our cobot concept could find a niche in these applications.

This I-Corps endeavor empowered our team to venture beyond the confines of the lab, immersing ourselves in the market dynamics and understanding the real-world application needs. The experiences garnered and the knowledge acquired have reshaped our research strategies and technical development roadmap, emphasizing a user-centric approach. Establishing strategic collaborations with key industry players for future development, testing, and application validation, the project significantly bolsters our prospects for successful commercialization endeavors ahead.

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2023
Modified by: Dongming Gan
